The Claim vs The Data

Opposition critics and certain media outlets have claimed that Reform UK "broke their promise" on council tax at Lancashire County Council. Labour's Mark Clifford called the 3.80% rise "a slap in the face." Azhar Ali called it "a massive hit" and accused Reform of breaking "their one big promise." North West Bylines ran the headline: "Reform to bin DOGE at Lancashire County Council and raise council tax instead."

Here is the council tax record — every year, verified from official council minutes.

Council Tax History: Lancashire County Council

YearAdministrationRiseNotes
2009/10–2012/13Conservative0%4-year freeze (Band D: £1,108.30)
2013/14Conservative−2.0%Pre-election cut (Band D: £1,086.13). Cost £187m over next decade

2026/27Reform UK3.80%Lowest rise in 12 years

The Inconvenient Facts

Fact 1: The Conservatives raised council tax to the legal maximum without a referendum in both 2024/25 and 2025/26 — 4.99% each time.

Fact 2: Their 2018/19 rise of 5.99% remains the highest in Lancashire County Council history.

Fact 3: In 7 of their 8 years in control, the Conservatives applied the maximum or near-maximum council tax increase available.

Fact 4: Reform's 3.80% (1.8% core + 2.0% adult social care precept) is the lowest council tax rise Lancashire has seen since 2014/15.

Fact 5: Reform's rise is 1.19 percentage points below the previous year's rate — saving a Band D household approximately £20 per year compared to what the Conservatives would have charged.

The £40 Million Windfall Argument

Conservatives argue that Reform is "£40 million per year better off" due to improved pension fund performance and additional government funding, yet only reduced the council tax increase by approximately £8.2 million.

This argument ignores that Reform inherited:

  • A £28 million projected overspend that had to be closed
  • A £10.6 million outturn overspend from the previous year
  • £93 million in additional demand pressures (£54 million service demand + £39 million inflation)
  • A savings delivery rate of just 48% — meaning over £35 million in planned Conservative savings never materialised
  • A DSG deficit of £95.5 million and rising

The "windfall" was consumed by the financial crisis left behind.

What the Critics Won't Tell You

In February 2013, the outgoing Conservative administration cut council tax by 2% — reducing Band D from £1,108.30 to £1,086.13 — in what Azhar Ali himself later called "a bribe" to voters before the May 2013 elections. Council officers calculated that this pre-election cut cost Lancashire £187 million cumulatively over the following decade through the compounding base effect.

Labour inherited this reduced tax base when they won the 2013 elections. Faced with £262 million in government austerity cuts, they closed 40 libraries, cut 59 bus routes, shut 5 museums, and made over 1,500 staff redundant during their 2013-2017 minority administration — a crisis made worse by the Conservatives' pre-election council tax giveaway.

Reform's 3.80% is the lowest in over a decade. It is not a broken promise — it is the most fiscally responsible council tax decision Lancashire has seen in years.
